page.title: 02Knowle Moor
page.content: Knowle Moor occupies the north-west corner of the area, covering about two square kilometres. It presents a typical picture of farming countryside on the Somerset levels. Rich,flat,green pastures are criss-crossed by a grid-like pattern of rhynes,the Somerset version of artifical drainage ditches,many of them marked by hedgerows and willow trees. The drainage was completed in the eighteenth century and today the land is grazed by both cattle and sheep,the majority of the cattle being Frisian dairy cows. Looking north-east across the moor from Bleadney the moor is dominated visually by Knowle Hill,despite its low height of 36 metres maximum. The name "Knowle" keeps recurring,as in Knowle Bridge(crossing the River Axe) and Knowle Farm.
